section.p: The following tables list summary commands available using the SLCmd program at the command line interface (CLI). To use the program, type SLCmd and the desired command. Type SLCmd and press ENTER to display the list of available commands

note.p: Only a administrator with Windows administrator privileges can use SLCmd at the command line interface (CLI). SLCmd will prompt for the administrator password before running certain commands.
The following is a full list of commands available using the SLCmd program.

section.title: General Commands
section.p: Perform general actions using the Command Line Interface.
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.
The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Activate the program using the specified license key.
Prompt the currently logged on administrator to specify a new password
Change the currently logged on administrator password to the newly specified password
Display the current Application Lockdown status

note.p: The default status is "disable".
The default status is "disable".

entry.p: Display a notification on the managed endpoint when blocks a file.
Do not display any notification when blocks a file.
Display a list of applications blocked by
Display the current status of the vulnerability attack prevention features
Display the current status of Application Lockdown and the auto update function of the Approved List
Display the current versions of components

section.title: Central Management Commands
section.p: Configure central management features using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
To illustrate, if users want to test the agent-server connection, type: SLCmd.exe -p <admin_password> test mm
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.
The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Decrypt the configuration file used by Managed Mode
Encrypt the configuration file used by Managed Mode
Export the encrypted configuration file used by Managed Mode
Export the encrypted StellarOne SSL communication certificate file
Import the encrypted configuration file used by Managed Mode
Import the encrypted StellarOne SSL communication certificate file

note.p: The default status is "disable".
The following optional parameters are available:

p.text: Use -cfg value to specify the path of the configuration file
Use -sc value to specify the path of the ertificate file

entry.p: Display the current Managed Mode status
Display the configuration used by Managed Mode
Connect a test Managed Mode session with StellarOne server

section.title: Optional Feature Commands
section.p: Configure optional security features using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.

entry.p: Manage actions taken when blocks specific types of events
Allows or blocks storage devices (CD/DVD drives, floppy disks, and network drives) from accessing the managed endpoint.
Manage Write Protection including the Approved List

section.p: The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Display the current status of API Hooking Prevention

note.p: The default status is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current setting for actions taken when blocks specific types of events

note.p: The default setting is "ask".

entry.p:
Ignore blocked files or processes when Application Lockdown blocks any of the following events:
Process launch
DLL loading
Script file access

Quarantine blocked files or processes when Application Lockdown blocks any of the following events:
Process launch
DLL loading
Script file access

note.p: does not support a custom action of “quarantine” on Windows (Standard) XP Embedded SP1.

entry.p:
Ask what to do for blocked files or processes when Application Lockdown blocks any of the following events:
Process launch
DLL loading
Script file access
Display the current status of DLL/Driver Lockdown

note.p: The default status is "enable".

entry.p: Display the current status of DLL Injection Prevention

note.p: The default status is "disable".

entry.p: Display current setting for using exceptions to Application Lockdown

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Integrity Monitoring

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Memory Randomization

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Network Virus Protection

note.p: The default setting is "enable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Script Lockdown

note.p: The default setting is "enable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Storage Device Blocking

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current status of USB Malware Protection

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Write Protection

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the current status of Write Protection including the Approved List

note.p: The default status is "disable". However, the status changes to "enabled" if Write Protection is enabled.

entry.p: Enable protection of the Approved List (in addition to the Write Protection List) when Write Protection is enabled
Disable protection of the Approved List (in addition to the Write Protection List) when Write Protection is enabled

section.title: Restricted User Account Commands

The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Display the Restricted User account status

note.p: The default status is "disable".

entry.p: Prompt the currently logged on administrator to specify a new Restricted User account password
Change the Restricted User account password to the newly specified password

section.title: Script Commands
section.p: Deploy scripts using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.
The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Add the specified script extension and the interpreter(s) required to execute the script
For example, to add the script extension JSP with the interpreter file jscript.js, type:
Remove the specified script extension and the interpreter(s) required to execute the script
For example, to remove the script extension JSP with the interpreter file jscript.js, type:

note.p: If you do not specify any interpreter, the command removes all interpreters related to the script extension. If you specify interpreters, the command only removes the interpreters specified from the script extension rule.

uses the following default script rules:
bat <cmd.exe>
cmd <cmd.exe>
com <ntvdm.exe>
dll <ntvdm.exe>
drv <ntvdm.exe>
exe <ntvdm.exe>
js <cscript.exe>, <wscript.exe>
msi <msiexec.exe>
pif <ntvdm.exe>
ps1 <powershell.exe>
sys <ntvdm.exe>
vbe <cscript.exe>, <wscript.exe
vbs <cscript.exe>, <wscript.exe

entry.p: Manage files in the Approved List
Manage the Approved List import and export functions

section.p: The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Add the specified file to the Approved List
For example, to add all Microsoft Office files to the Approved List, type:

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders.

entry.p: Remove the specified file from the Approved List
For example, to remove notepad.exe from the Approved List, type:
Display the files in the Approved List
Update the hash values in the Approved List and display detailed results
Update the hash values in the Approved List and display summarized results
Compare the hash values in the Approved List with the hash values calculated from the actual files and prompt the user after detecting mismatched values
Export the Approved List to the file path and file name specified

note.p: The output file type must be DB format.

entry.p: Import an Approved List from the file path and file name specified

note.p: The input file type must be DB format. Using the optional -o value overwrites the existing list.

section.title: Application Lockdown Commands
section.p: Perform actions related to Application Lockdown using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.

note.p: supports extended regular expressions (ERE). For more information, see .

section.p: The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Display a list of quarantined files
Restore the specified file from quarantine. Using the optional -al value also adds the restored file to the Approved List. Using the optional -f value forces the restore.
Display current exceptions to Application Lockdown
Add an exception for the specified file
Add an exception for the specified folder
Add an exception for the specified folder and related subfolders
Add an exception using the regular expression
Add an exception for the specified file
Remove an exception for the specified folder

note.p: Specify the exact <folder_path> originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove an exception for the specified folder and related subfolders

note.p: Specify the exact <folder_path> originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove an exception using the regular expression

note.p: Specify the exact <regular_expression> originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Check if the regular expression matches the string

p.userinput: LCmd.exe -p <admin_password> test exceptionpath C:\\test\\.* C:\\test \\sample.exe -t regexp

section.title: Write Protection Commands
section.p: Configure Write Protection List and Write Protection Exception List using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.

entry.p: Manage files in the Write Protection List
Manage folders in the Write Protection List
Manage registry values and associated registry keys in the Write Protection List
Manage registry keys in the Write Protection List
Manage files in the Write Protection Exception List
Manage folders in the Write Protection Exception List
Manage registry values and associated registry keys in the Write Protection Exception List
Manage registry keys in the Write Protection Exception List

section.p: The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Display the entire Write Protection List
Display the files in the Write Protection List
Display the files in the Write Protection Exception List
Display the folders in the Write Protection List
Display the folders in the Write Protection Exception List
Add the specified file to the Write Protection List

note.p: The value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matches c:\Windows \userfile.txt and c:\Temp \userfile.txt.

entry.p: Add the specified file and a specific process path for that file to the Write Protection Exception List
For example, to add write access by a process named notepad.exe to a file named userfile.txt, type:

note.p: The -p and -t values pattern match from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matches c:\Windows \userfile.txt and c:\Temp \userfile.txt.

entry.p: Add the specified file to the Write Protection Exception List
For example, to add write access by any process to a file named userfile.txt, type:

note.p: The -t value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matches c:\Windows \userfile.txt and c:\Temp\userfile.txt.

entry.p: Add the specified process path to the Write Protection Exception List
For example, to add write access by a process named notepad.exe to any files, type:

note.p: The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying notepad.exe matches c:\Windows \notepad.exe and c:\Temp\notepad.exe.

entry.p: Add the specified folder(s) to the Write Protection List

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders.
The value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matchesc:\Windows \userfolder and c:\Temp \userfolder.

entry.p: Add the specified folder and processes run from the specified path to the Write Protection Exception List
For example, to add write access by a process named notepad.exe to a folder and related subfolders at c:\Windows \System32\Temp, type:

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders. The -p and -t values pattern match from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matches c:\Windows \userfile.txt and c:\Temp\userfile.txt.

entry.p: Add the specified folder(s) to the Write Protection Exception List
For example, to add write access by any process to a folder at userfolder, type:

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders. The -t value pattern matches from the last part of the folder path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfolder matches c:\Windows \userfolder and c:\Temp \userfolder.

entry.p: Add processes run from the specified paths to the Write Protection Exception List
For example, to add write access by a process named notepad.exe to any folder, type:

note.p: The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying notepad.exe matches c:\Windows \notepad.exe and c:\Temp\notepad.exe.

entry.p: Remove the specified file from the Write Protection List

note.p: Specify the exact <file_path> originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove the specified file and process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: Specify the exact <file_path> and <process_path> originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove the specified file from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: The -t value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matches c:\Windows \userfile.txt and c:\Temp \userfile.txt.

entry.p: Remove the specified process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying notepad.exe matches c:\Windows \notepad.exe and c:\Temp \notepad.exe.

entry.p: Remove the specified folder(s) from the Write Protection List

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders. Specify the exact <folder_path> and -r value originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove the specified folder and process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders. Specify the exact <folder_path>, <process_path>, and -r value originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove the specified folder(s) from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders. The -t value pattern matches from the last part of the folder path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfolder matches c:\Windows \userfolder and c:\Temp \userfolder.

entry.p: Remove the specified process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying notepad.exe matches c:\Windows \notepad.exe and c:\Temp \notepad.exe.

entry.p: Display the entire Write Protection List
Display the registry values in the Write Protection List
Display the registry values in the Write Protection Exception List
Display the registry keys in the Write Protection List
Display the registry keys in the Write Protection Exception List
Add the specified registry value and its related registry key to the Write Protection List
For example, to add the registry value of “testvalue” in the “HKEY \test” registry key to the Write Protection List, type:
Add the specified registry value and its related registry key and a specific process path for that value to the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: This command allows write access by the specified process to the specified registry values. The -p value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Add the specified registry value and its related registry key to the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: This command allows write access by any process to the specified registry value.

entry.p: Add the specified process to the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: This command allows write access by the specified process to any registry values. The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Add the specified registry key to the Write Protection List

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified registry key and related subkeys.

entry.p: Add the specified registry key and processes run from the specified path to the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: This command allows write access by the specified process to the specified registry keys.
Using the optional -r value includes the specified registry key and related subkeys.
The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Add the specified registry key to the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: This command allows write access by any process to the specified registry keys.
Using the optional -r value includes the specified registry key and related subkeys.

entry.p: Add processes run from the specified paths to the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: This command allows write access by the specified process to any registry keys.
The -p value pattern matches from the end of the process path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Remove the specified registry value from the Write Protection List

note.p: Specify the exact <path_of _registry_key> and <registry_value>originally specified in the corresponding add command.

entry.p: Remove the specified registry value and process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: Specify the exact <path_of _registry_key>, <registry_value>, and <process_path> originally specified in the corresponding add command.
The -p value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Remove the specified registry value from the Write Protection Exception List
Remove the specified process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: The -p value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Remove the specified registry key from the Write Protection List

note.p: Specify the exact <path_of_registry_key> and -r value originally specified in the corresponding add command.
Using the optional -r value includes the specified registry key and related subkeys

entry.p: Remove the specified registry key and process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: Specify the exact <path_of_registry_key>, <process_path>, and -r value originally specified in the corresponding add command.
Using the optional -r value includes the specified registry key and related subkeys.
The -p value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path.

entry.p: Remove the specified registry key from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified registry key and related subkeys.

entry.p: Remove the specified process path from the Write Protection Exception List

note.p: The -p value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path.

section.p: Configure Trusted Certificates using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:

entry.p: Display current setting for using Trusted Certifications

note.p: The default setting is "enable".

entry.p: Display the certificate files in the Trusted Certifications List
Using the optional -v value displays detailed information.
Add the specified certificate file to the Trusted Certifications List
Using the optional -l value specifies the unique label for this certificate file
Using the optional -u value treats the file signed by this certificate file as a Trusted Updater
Remove a certificate file from the Trusted Certifications List by specifying its label

section.title: Trusted Hash List Commands
section.p: Configure trusted hash values using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.

entry.p: Manage trusted hash values (files) added by the administrator

section.p: The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Display current setting for using Trusted Hash List

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Display the hash values in the Trusted Hash List
Add the specified hash value to the Trusted Hash List
For example, to add a trusted file with a hash value xxx to the Trusted Hash List, type:
Using the optional -l value specifies the unique label for this hash value.
Using the optional -u value treats the file of the specified hash value as a Trusted Updater.

note.p: The -u value requires the Predefined Trusted Updater List enabled.

entry.p: Using the optional -al value adds the file of the specified hash value to Approved List
Using the optional -t value specifies a file path to check for the hash value

note.p: The -t value pattern matches from the end of the path toward the beginning of the path. For example, specifying userfile.txt matches c:\Windows\userfile.txtand c:\Temp\userfile.txt.

entry.p: Using the optional -n value adds a note for the file hash
Remove a file from the Trusted Hash List by specifying its label
Remove all the hash values in the Trusted Hash List

entry.p: Start Trusted Updater to add installer files (EXE and MSI file types) to the specified folder of the Approved List
For example, to include all installation packages in the C:\Installers folder and all sub-folders, type:

note.p: Using the optional -r value includes the specified folder and related subfolders.

entry.p: Disable Trusted Updater to stop adding new or updated files to the Approved List
For example, to stop the Trusted Updater and commit all identified installers (identified before receiving the stop command) to the Approved List after receiving a prompt, type:

note.p: Using the optional -f value specifies that the Trusted Updater does not prompt the administrator before committing a file to the Approved List.

For example, to add notepad.exe to the Predefined Trusted Updater Exception List, type:

For details on adding files to the Predefined Trusted Updater List (not the Predefined Trusted Updater Exception List), see Predefined Trusted Updater "Add" Command in the following section.

entry.p: Decrypt a file to the specified location
For example, to decrypt C:\Notepad.xen to C:\Editors\notepad.xml, type:
Encrypt a file to the specified location
For example, to encrypt C:\notepad.xml to C:\Editors\Notepad.xen, type:
Export the Predefined Trusted Updater List to the specified encrypted file
Import a Predefined Trusted Updater List from the specified encrypted file
Remove the specified labeled rule from the Predefined Trusted Updater List
For example, to remove the “Notepad” rule, type:
Remove the specified exception from the Predefined Trusted Updater Exception List
For example, to remove the notepad.exe exception, type:
Display the status of the Predefined Trusted Updater List

note.p: The default setting is "disable".

entry.p: Enable the Predefined Trusted Updater List
Disable the Predefined Trusted Updater List
Display the files in the Predefined Trusted Updater List
Display the files in the Predefined Trusted Updater Exception List

note.p: The "add" command for adding files to the Predefined Trusted Updater List follows a different format than the general commands specified in the Predefined Trusted Updater Commands table. For details on adding files to the Predefined Trusted Updater List, refer to the Predefined Trusted Updater "Add" Command in the following section.

section.title: Predefined Trusted Updater "Add" Command
section.p: Add processes, files, or folders to the Predefined Trusted Updater List using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the command, parameter, and base value.

entry.p: Add a specified file or folder to the Predefined Trusted Updater List
For example, to add notepad.exe to the Predefined Trusted Updater List, type:

section.p: Append the following additional values at the end of the command:

entry.p: Add the specified file or folder to the Predefined Trusted Updater List

note.p: This parameter requires the use of the -t <type_of_object> value.

entry.p: Specify the type of object to add to the Predefined Trusted Updater List located in -u <folder_or_file>
Available objects types are as follows:

li.p: process: Indicates only EXE file types
file: Indicates only MSI and BAT file types
folder: Indicates all EXE, MSI, and BAT files in the specified folder
folderandsub: Indicates all EXE, MSI, and BAT files in the specified folder and related subfolders

row.entry: Add the full file path to the specified parent process used to invoke the file(s) specified in -u <folder_or_file>

p.userinput: SLCmd.exe -p <admin_password> add predefinedtrust edupdater -u C:\Windows\notepad.exe -t process -p C:\batch files\note.bat

entry.p: Specify a label name for the file(s) specified in -u <folder_or_file>

note.p: When left blank, assigns an arbitrary label name.

p.userinput: SLCmd.exe -p <admin_password> add predefinedtrustedupdater -u C:\Windows\notepad.exe -t process -l EDITOR

entry.p: Compare the hash values in the Approved List with the hash values calculated from the actual files

note.p: Enabled by default even when -al is not specified.

p.userinput: SLCmd.exe -p <admin_password> add predefinedtrustedupdater -u C:\Windows\notepad.exe -t process -al enable

entry.p: Do not compare the hash values in the Approved List with the hash values calculated from the actual files

p.userinput: SLCmd.exe -p <admin_password> add predefinedtrustedupdater -u C:\Windows \notepad.exe -t process -al disable

section.title: Fileless Attack Prevention Commands
section.p: Configure Fileless Attack Prevention features using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:
The following table lists the available abbreviated forms of parameters.
The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Display the current Fileless Attack Prevention status
Display the list of monitored processes
Add a Fileless Attack Prevention exception
For example, given the following exception:

li.p: Monitored Process: cscript.exe
Parentprocess1: a.exe
Parentprocess2:
Parentprocess3: c.exe
Parentprocess4:
Arguments: -abc –def
Use regular expression for arguments: No

p.userinput: SLCmd.exe -p <admin_password> addflpe cscript.exe a.exe "" c.exe "" -a "-abc – def"

entry.p: Remove a Fileless Attack Prevention exception

li.p: If a monitored process is launched before is started, is unable to detect and block the monitored process.

In systems running Windows Vista x86 (no service pack installed), the Fileless Attack Prevention feature can run the process chain check without issues, but is unable to perform the command line argument check. If a process passes the process chain check on these systems, the command line argument check is skipped completely.

entry.p: Set an action to take place after Maintenance Mode as well as a duration for Maintenance Mode in hours (1 -999)
Start Maintenance Mode and enable file scanning after the maintenance period
will scan files that are created/executed/modified during the maintenance period and quarantines detected files, then add files that are not detected as malicious to the Approved List

Start Maintenance Mode and enable file scanning after the maintenance period. scans files that are created/ executed/modified files during the period and adds these files (including files that aredetected as malicious) to the Approved List

note.p: You cannot stop Maintenance Mode when an agent is preparing to leave Maintenance Mode.

entry.p: Stop Maintenance Mode and do not add files in the file queue to the Approved List

note.p: You cannot stop Maintenance Mode when an agent is preparing to leave Maintenance Mode.

entry.p: Set the schedule for Maintenance Mode

li.p: You cannot set the Maintenance Mode schedule when an agent is already in Maintenance Mode or is preparing to leave Maintenance Mode.
If you configure the Maintenance Mode schedule to start earlier than the current time, the system starts the maintenance period immediately after you save the settings.

entry.p: Use this command to configure the following:

li.p: Set the schedule for Maintenance Mode

Enable file scanning after the maintenance period: will scan files that are created/executed/modified during the maintenance period, quarantine detected threats, and add files that are not detected as malicious to the Approved List
You cannot set the Maintenance Mode schedule when an agent is already in Maintenance Mode or is preparing to leave Maintenance Mode.
If you configure the Maintenance Mode schedule to start earlier than the current time, the system starts the maintenance period immediately after you save the settings.

entry.p: Use this command to configure the following:

li.p: Set the schedule for Maintenance Mode

Enable file scanning after the maintenance period: will scan files that are created/executed/modified during the maintenance period and add these files (including files that are detected as malicious) to the Approved List
You cannot set the Maintenance Mode schedule when an agent is already in Maintenance Mode or is preparing to leave Maintenance Mode.
If you configure the Maintenance Mode schedule to start earlier than the current time, the system starts the maintenance period immediately after you save the settings.

entry.p: Clear the Maintenance Mode schedule settings

note.p: You cannot delete schedule settings when an agent is already in Maintenance Mode or is preparing to leave Maintenance Mode.

entry.p: Display the Maintenance Mode schedule settings

note.p: Before using Maintenance Mode, apply the required updates on the following supported platforms:

li.p: For Windows 2000 Service Pack 4, apply the update KB891861 from the Microsoft Update Catalog website.
For Windows XP SP1, upgrade to Windows XP SP2.
To reduce risk of infection, run only applications from trusted sources on endpoints during the maintenance period.
Agents start one scheduled maintenance period at a time. If you configure a new maintenance period, the system overwrites existing maintenance schedule that has not started yet.
When the agent is about to leave Maintenance Mode, restarting the agent endpoint prevents from adding files in the queue to the Approved List.
During the maintenance period, you cannot perform agent patch updates on endpoints.
When Maintenance Mode is enabled, does not support Windows updates that require restarting an endpoint during the maintenance period.
To run an installer that deploys files to a network folder during the maintenance period, must have access permission to the network folder.
Maintenance Mode does not support the Windows Visual Studio debugger.

section.title: Manual Scan Commands
section.p: Perform actions related to manual scans on endpoints using the Command Line Interface by typing your command in the following format:

li.p: The Manual Scan commands require special licensing. Ensure that you choose the correct license edition before using Manual Scan commands. For more information on how to obtain the required license edition, contact your sales representative.
For agent component updates, make sure that agents can connect to an update source without using a proxy server.
After a component update is complete, you cannot roll back the component to a previous version

section.p: The following table lists the commands, parameters, and values available.

entry.p: Start a manual scan on an endpoint
Use the -action option to specify an action to perform when an anomaly is detected

li.p: 0: No action
1: Clean, or delete if the clean action is unsuccessfu
2: Clean, or quarantine if the clean action is unsuccessful
This is the default action.
3: Clean, or ignore if the clean action is unsuccessful
For each manual scan, saves the scan results in a log file (with a file name of ScanResult_YYYYMMDDHHMMSS.log) in C:\Program Files\TXOne\StellarProtect (Legacy Mode)StellarEnforce \Scan\log.
With administrator privileges, you can restore quarantined files using the following command:
where <QuarantinedFilePath> is the file path of the quarantined file and <FilePathToRestore> is the folder location to restore the file. For information about quarantined files, see the scan logs.

entry.p: Update StellarProtect (Legacy Mode)StellarEnforce agent components (pattern file and scan engine)
Set the update source for component updates
